newsitem.title: DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO: Kinshasa girls say harassed over mini-skirts.
newsitem.headline: Kinshasa girls say harassed over mini-skirts.

text.p: Girls in Kinshasa, once one of Africa's liveliest capitals with a nightlife to match, say they are wrapping up in public in response to harassment by Laurent Kabila's soldiers for wearing mini-skirts or tight trousers.
"We all carry a wraparound skirt to wear to and from the clubs. We are very frightened," Alice, a part-time prostitute outside one of the city's seedier night spots, told Reuters.
It is not only prostitutes who have readjusted their dress sense. A young translator waiting for a taxi at 10 p.m. was threatened last week by three soldiers.

"They said it was not Congolese to wear trousers. They told me I would be killed if I did not take them off. When I did they burnt them on the side of the road and left me half-naked," she told Reuters.
Kabila's government, which renamed Africa's third largest country the Democratic Republic of Congo after marching into the capital on May 17, says there is no ban.

"It is a small problem resulting from the excess of zeal on the part of some soldiers," governent spokesman Raphael Ghenda told journalists. "In a period of change there are many intitiatives which are taken precipitately."
But Kabila's deputy, Deogratias Bugera, has called for what he called "a clean-up of public morals".
Residents say that shortly after the rebel takeover, local language announcers on national radio spoke out against mini- skirts and tight trousers.
A French-language announcer at the end of last week said he was happy to note that the city's women were now wearing "more suitable attire".
Many of Kabila's troops, some of whom were recruited during his seven-month march across the country, have never been to a city the size of Kinshasa before.
